[[File:محمدعلی سرلک 2.gpg.jpg|thumb|right|Prof.Mohammad Ali Sarlak]] ''' Mohammad Ali Sarlak''' (born March 25, 1970, Iran) is an International author and researcher.<ref>[https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=Fx08B9MAAAAJ&hl=en Google Scholar list of publications by Mohammad Ali Sarlak and related citations]</ref> He is a [[professor]] of organizational behavior management at [[Payame Noor University]] (PNU), and current president of post graduate center of this university.<ref name="pnu.ac.ir">http://www.pnu.ac.ir/portal/Home/Default.aspx?CategoryID=90c596fd-f593-4b7b-a3a3-d4f54fa0f29f</ref> He is known for introducing new concept of [[the organization’s face]] in a multi volume book entitled:The new faces of organizations in the 21st century<ref>https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=dp_byline_sr_book_1?ie=UTF8&text=Mohammad+A.+Sarlak&search-alias=books&field-author=Mohammad+A.+Sarlak&sort=relevancerank</ref><ref name=sarlak2011>Sarlak, Mohammad. A. (2011). ''The New Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volumes:1,2,3)''. Canada: NAISIT Publishers.</ref><ref name=sarlak2012>Sarlak, Mohammad. A. (2012). ''The New Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volumes:4,5)''. Canada: NAISIT Publishers.</ref> and as well as for his role as past president of the [[Payame Noor University]] as one of the world's [[Mega Universities]]. [[File:Professor_Mohammad_Ali_Sarlak_-UNESCO_World_Summit-2015-Paris.jpg|thumb|right| Professor Mohammad Ali Sarlak-UNESCO World Summit-2015-Paris]]
==Education== Ph.D: Organizational Behavior Management, [[University of Tehran]], 2005.
M.B.A: [[University of Tehran]], 1995.
B.S: Business Administration, [[University of Tehran]], 1993.
==Ideas and Concepts== Much of prof. sarlak's works concentrated on Advancing the boundaries of management knowledge. Some of his new ideas and conceptualizations are as follows:
'''-''' [[The organization’s face]]
'''-''' The organizational Rip currents.<ref>https://jipa.ut.ac.ir/article_62176_en.html</ref>
'''-''' The Commotion–result Theory .<ref> http://journals.pnu.ac.ir/article_3622_4.html</ref> .<ref> https://www.omicsonline.org/open-access/identification-of-the-strategies-of-organizational-brawl-management-2162-6359-1000427.php?aid=89657</ref>
'''-''' Management by Reaction .<ref>http://upna.ir/?p=51303</ref>
'''-''' The organizational Climate Inversion .<ref> http://modamnet.com/product/%D9%88%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%86%DA%AF%DB%8C-%D8%AC%D9%88-%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C/</ref>
'''-''' The Behavioral Entropy .<ref> http://www.iran-academy.org/%D9%85%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8-%D8%A2%D9%85%D9%88%D8%B2%D8%B4%DB%8C/838-%DA%86%D8%B1%D8%A7-%D8%B1%D9%81%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%B1-%DA%A9%D8%A7%D8%B1%DA%A9%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AA%D8%BA%DB%8C%DB%8C%D8%B1-%D9%85%DB%8C-%DA%A9%D9%86%D8%AF%D8%9F.html</ref>
'''-''' The organizational Life Expectancy .<ref> http://modamnet.com/product/%D8%A7%D9%85%DB%8C%D8%AF-%D8%A8%D9%87-%D8%B2%D9%86%D8%AF%DA%AF%DB%8C-%D8%B3%D8%A7%D8%B2%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%DB%8C/</ref>
==Positions== '''-''' President of [[Payame Noor University]] (PNU) (2014–2015).
'''-''' President of Post Graduate Center of [[Payame Noor University]] (2007–Present).<ref name="pnu.ac.ir"/>
'''-''' A member of Executive Committee of AAOU (Asian Association of Open Universities) in 2015 .<ref>http://aaou.ouhk.edu.hk/about.htm</ref>
'''-''' A board member of Iranian Academy of Management sciences (2016).<ref>http://www.iams.ir/fa/NewsDetails.aspx?NewsId=1038</ref>
'''-''' A member of the Central promotion Committee of the Ministry of Science ,Research and Technology (2015–present).<ref>http://www.irna.ir/fa/News/81610749/</ref>
'''-''' A member of the National Committee of UNESCO (2015–present).<ref>http://www.mehrnews.com/news/2896487</ref>
'''-''' The Establisher of a UNESCO Chair on Environmental Education <ref>http://iranunesco.ir/project/en/news/58/</ref>
'''-''' A member of policymaking and scientific council of Iran Inventions Grand Prize<ref>http://iigp.ir/en/ScientificBoard.aspx</ref>
==Journals Editor in chief== 1. Iranian journal of Management of public organizations <ref>http://ipom.journals.pnu.ac.ir</ref>(2013–present)
2. International Journal of the Academy of Organizational Behavior Management, CANADA<ref>http://www.iaobm.ca/journal</ref>(2012–2014).
3. International Journal of E-Entrepreneurship and Innovation (IJEEI), IGI, USA<ref>https://www.amazon.com/International-Journal-E-Entrepreneurship-Innovation-Mohammad/dp/1616929782</ref>(2010–2012).
==Published Books== 1. The New Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 1), NAISIT, 2011, CANADA
2. The New Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 2), NAISIT, 2011, CANADA
3. The New Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 3) , NAISIT, 2011, CANADA
4. The New Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 4) , NAISIT, 2012, CANADA
5. The New Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 5) , NAISIT, 2012, CANADA
6. E-Banking and Emerging Multidisciplinary Processes, IGI,2011, USA.
7. Barriers of E-Commerce Acceptance in Export, LAMBERT,2011,USA.
8. The Emerging Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 1),Knowledge Reference Publisher,2013,IRAN.
9. The Emerging Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 2),Knowledge Reference Publisher,2013,IRAN.
10. The Emerging Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 3),Knowledge Reference Publisher,2013,IRAN.
11. The Emerging Faces of Organizations in the 21st Century (Volume 4),Knowledge Reference Publisher,2013,IRAN.
12. The organizations in knowledge Era ,Payame Noor Publisher,edition2,2012,IRAN.
13. Advanced Management Information Systems, Payame Noor Publisher, edition2. , 2011,IRAN.
14. Healthy Organization in Practice, Knowledge Reference Publisher,2014,IRAN.
15. E-Government, Knowledge Reference Publisher,2013,IRAN.
16. Managing Organizational trauma, Mir Mah Press,2016,IRAN.
17. Trauma Management from Islam View point., Mir Mah Press,2016,IRAN.
18. The new era of management,(Richard.L.Daft): Translated in Farsi By Dr.Sarlak , Gostareh,Press, 2008,IRAN.
==Research Works== He has published over one hundred scientific papers<ref>https://scholar.google.com/scholar?hl=en&q=mohammad+ali+sarlak&btnG=&as_sdt=1%2C5&as_sdtp=</ref> and directed more than 250 master's thesis<ref>http://www.pnu.ac.ir/portal/File/ShowFile.aspx?ID=c03b9522-22ea-4415-b7a1-7723a2951306</ref> and doctoral dissertations.<ref>http://www.pnu.ac.ir/portal/File/ShowFile.aspx?ID=807dafb9-c5bb-4619-95f1-2481a4ea89aa</ref>
==The concept of organization’s face == The concept of organization’s face represents something that identifies and distinguishes the organization from other similar organizations. This concept is based on tow underlying metaphors: # The organization as a natural system.<ref name=scott1998>Scott, W. Richard. (1998). ''Organizations: Rational, Natural, and Open Systems, 4th edn ''. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice-Hall.</ref> # The organization as an organism<ref name=morgan2006>Morgan, Gareth. (2006). ''Images of Organization''. Newbury Park. CA: Sage Publications.</ref> The Organizations as living entity such as humans can be distinguished by face factor from each other. The question is what are the factors that determine an organization’s face? To answer this question, should be attention to pillars of an organization.<ref name="scott1998"/> Every organization has at least five following pillars.<ref name="scott1998"/> : # People # Goals # Structure # Technology # Environment
With an emphasis on each of the organizational pillars, a specific type of organization’s face is formed.Every organization can demonstrate five general face, simultaneously or separately: # Humanistic face # Goal oriented face # Structure oriented face # Technology based face # Environment based face Each of these faces is divided into more specific faces.

[[Image:Familytreeofmuthoot.jpg|thumb|700px|right| Muthoot Family]]
The '''Muthoot family''' is one of the foremost business houses in [[South India]]. The family has interests in various sectors of business varying from [[Financial Services]] to [[Mass media|Media]]. The founder of the [[Muthoot|Muthoot Group]] was Ninan Mathai Muthoot, from whom the business house was later taken over by his son, [[M. George Muthoot]]. The family traces its roots to the small town of [[Kozhencherry]] in [[Central Travancore]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://muthootgroup.com/php/showContent.php?linkid=1&partid=2 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090302224725/http://muthootgroup.com/php/showContent.php?linkid=1&partid=2 |archivedate=2009-03-02 |df= }}</ref>
The Muthoot family are Christians belonging to the [[Malankara Orthodox Syrian Church]], and is one of the most influential members among the Christian community in [[Kerala]]. [[M. G. George Muthoot]], the third son of M. George Muthoot became the Trustee of the Malankara Orthodox Church in March 2007.<ref>http://www.orthodoxherald.com/2007/03/19/fr-johns-abraham-konattu-and-muthoot-m-g-george-as-trustees-of-the-church/</ref>
[[India Today]] rated the Muthoot Family among the most influential business houses in Kerala. [[Dhanam (Business Magazine)|Dhanam]] (Wealth), a business magazine in Kerala, also rated Muthoot as one of the foremost business families of Kerala.<ref>http://www.dhanammagazine.com/index.php?issueid=125</ref>
The Muthoot M. George Charitable Trust reaches over 20,000 people in need of assistance every year.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} The Trust is engaged in various activities such as Disaster Relief, Community Development and Social Welfare.

{{EngvarB|date=January 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Paddy Cosgrave | image = Sportsfile (Web Summit) (22554473410) (cropped).jpg | alt = | caption = Cosgrave at [[Web Summit]] 2015 | birth_name = Patrick Cosgrave | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |31 |2014|November|4}}<ref name=Connolly /> | birth_place = [[County Wicklow]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=y|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | nationality = Irish | other_names = | occupation = Entrepreneur | years_active = | known_for = Co-founder of [[Web Summit]] | notable_works = }} '''Paddy Cosgrave''' is an Irish entrepreneur. He is a co-founder of [[Web Summit]], an annual technology conference, and CEO of the company that runs Web Summit and other events. In 2015 he was listed 18th in the ''[[Wired UK]]'' list of the most influential people in Europe in the field of technology.
==Early life and education==
Patrick "Paddy" Cosgrave grew up on a farm in [[County Wicklow]].<ref name=Connolly>{{Cite news| last = Connolly| first = Philip| title = Profile: Web Summit founder Paddy Cosgrave| work = The Daily Business Post| location = Dublin| date = 4 November 2014| accessdate= 28 September 2015 | url = http://www.businesspost.ie/#!story/Home/News/Profile%3A+Web+Summit+founder+Paddy+Cosgrave/id/87198161-2385-4588-f459-38f593406155}}</ref> He was educated at [[Glenstal Abbey School]] and [[Trinity College Dublin]], where he studied Business, Economics and Social Studies (BESS).<ref name=Duggan>{{Cite news| last = Duggan| first = Barry| title = Top school enrols boys who won't start classes until 2027| work = Sunday Independent| accessdate = 28 September 2015| date = 20 September 2015| url = http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/education/top-school-enrols-boys-who-wont-start-classes-until-2027-31541815.html}}</ref><ref name=Madeiros>{{Cite web| last = Medeiros| first = Joao| title = Scaling Dublin's Summit| work = [[Wired UK]]| accessdate = 28 September 2015| date = 5 January 2015| url = https://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2015/03/start/scaling-dublin-summit}}</ref> While at Trinity he was president of the [[University Philosophical Society]] (The Phil) and editor of ''[[The Piranha|Piranha]]'', a satirical college magazine.<ref name=Crowley>{{Cite news| pages = 15–16| last = Crowley| first = Aoife| title = Spinning a web summit| work = Trinity Today|year = 2013| accessdate= 28 September 2015| url = http://issuu.com/ashvillemedia/docs/trinity_today_2013_black?e=12657295/9231531}}</ref> During his presidency of The Phil, the society introduced [[University Philosophical Society#Phil Speaks|Phil Speaks]], an outreach initiative aimed at promoting debating and public speaking in Irish secondary schools. Cosgrave graduated with a BA from Trinity College, Dublin's BESS program in 2006.<ref name="Keenan&O'Hare">{{cite web|last1=Keenan|first1=Lisa|last2=O'Hare|first2=Aidan|title=''Universities, Societies & Clubs. Culture, Extracurricular Activities & Career Progression: Trinity College Dublin, Four Case Studies''|url=https://creativitythecityandtheuniversity.files.wordpress.com/2012/03/universitiessocietiesclubs20102.pdf|publisher=Trinity Long Room Hub|accessdate=29 September 2015|page=19|year=2010}}</ref><ref name=WorldEF>{{Cite web| title = Paddy Cosgrave| work = [[World Economic Forum]]| accessdate = 29 September 2015| url = http://www.weforum.org/contributors/paddy-cosgrave}}</ref>
==Career==
Cosgrave was one of the organizers and the executive director of Rock the Vote Ireland, a campaign launched in April 2007 to encourage young people to vote in the May 2007 [[Irish general election, 2007|Irish general election]].<ref name=celebrities>{{Cite news| last = Kane| first = Conor| title = Celebrities call on young people to rock the vote| work = [[Irish Examiner]]| accessdate = 29 September 2015| date = 21 March 2007| url = http://www.irishexaminer.com/ireland/politics/celebrities-call-on-young-people-to-rock-the-vote-28358.html}}</ref> He was also a co-founder of MiCandidate, a website that "provided detailed information on every candidate running in the 2007 general election".<ref name=Crowley /> MiCandidate expanded its scope to become a syndicator of news and information about European politicians to media organisations. The company was sold for "an undisclosed sum" in October 2009.<ref name=buyout>{{Cite web| last = Kennedy| first = John| title = Political media start-up MiCandidate acquired in MBO| work = Silicon Republic| date = 7 October 2009| accessdate=29 September 2015|url = https://www.siliconrepublic.com/companies/2009/10/07/political-media-start-up-micandidate-acquired-in-mbo}}</ref>
Cosgrave is a co-founder of the Web Summit and F.ounders conferences, and the CEO of Ci, the company that runs the two conferences and other events. F.ounders is an invitation-only event first held in Dublin in October 2009. The first Dublin Web Summit in November 2010 was attended by approximately 400 people.<ref name=Madeiros /> The fourth annual Web Summit in November 2014 had an attendance of over 22,000, and 30,000 were expected to attend the event in Dublin in November 2015. Starting in 2016, the Web Summit was held in Lisbon, although Ci continued to be headquartered in Dublin.<ref name=Temperton>{{Cite news| last = Temperton| first = James| title = Web Summit 2016 will ditch Dublin for Lisbon| work = Wired UK| date = 23 September 2015| accessdate=29 September 2015|url = https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2015-09/23/web-summit-dublin-lisbon-2016}}</ref> In 2014 Ci began introducing new events in the United States (Collision) and Hong Kong (RISE), with an event called SURGE planned for February 2016 in India.<ref name=nextchapter>{{Cite web| last = Cosgrave| first = Paddy| title = The Next Chapter| work = Web Summit Blog| date = 23 September 2015| accessdate=29 September 2015|url = http://blog.websummit.net/the-next-chapter/}}</ref>
Cosgrave was awarded the 2015 Irish Exporters Association annual gold medal.<ref name=IEA>{{Cite web| title = Exporters Association presents Gold Medal to Paddy Cosgrave, Web Summit at IEA President's Lunch at The Shelbourne Hotel, Dublin| work = Irish Exporters Association| accessdate = 29 September 2015| date=12 June 2015|url = http://www.irishexporters.ie/exporters-association-presents-gold-medal-to-paddy-cosgrave-web-summit-at-iea-presidents-lunch-at-the-shelbourne-hotel-dublin/}}</ref> He was listed 18th in the 2015 ''[[Wired UK]]'' list of the "100 most influential individuals in the wider ''Wired'' world".<ref>{{cite web|title=The 2015 WIRED 100|url=https://www.wired.co.uk/magazine/archive/2015/09/features/the-2015-wired-100/viewall|website=Wired UK|accessdate=29 September 2015|date=6 August 2015|quote=The only rules for nomination to the WIRED 100 are that the individuals must have a strong European connection, if not a base here; and they are being judged on their influence today, rather than historic achievements or funding raised.}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{advert|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox company | name = Panaya | logo = Panaya - an Infosys company.png | logo_size = 222 | logo_caption = | type = [[Privately held company]] | industry = Enterprise Software | founder = Yossi Cohen | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Jake Klein (CEO) | products = The Panaya CloudQuality Suite | services = [[Software as a service]] | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | assets = | equity = | members = | num_employees = | parent = [[Infosys]] | divisions = | subsid = | website = {{URL|www.panaya.com}} | foundation = {{start date|2006}} in Ra'anana, Israel | location_city = [[Hod Hasharon]] | location_country = [[Israel]] }} '''Panaya''' is an Israeli software company. The company is a subsidiary of [[Infosys]]. Panaya's products include [[Change impact analysis]], automated code remediation, collaborative [[Test management tools|test management]] and test-execution, and [[Application lifecycle management|ALM]] acceleration. Panaya’s service runs on the [[Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud]].<ref name="ZDNet">{{cite web | url=http://www.zdnet.com/article/panaya-a-different-kind-of-erp-third-party-maintenance-provider/ | title=Panaya – A different kind of ERP third party maintenance provider | publisher=ZDNet | date=7 January 2010 | accessdate=5 December 2014 | author=Sommer, Brian}}</ref>
==History==
Panaya was founded in 2006 as ''ChangeSoft Technologies'' by entrepreneur [[Yossi Cohen]] and is headquartered in [[Ra'anana, Israel]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.menlopark.com/directory-listing/Panaya/331527 | title=Panaya in Menlo Park | publisher=Menlo Park | accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref>
The disruptive technology revolves around the impact analyses of code change, applied in code comparison of [[Enterprise resource planning]] (ERP) systems to help reduce the application life cycle cost.<ref>{{ cite patent | country =US | number =2009216712 | status = | title =Methods for calculating a combined impact analysis repository | pubdate =27 August 2009 | gdate = | fdate = | pridate = | inventor =Cohen, Yossi; Cohen, Mati; Dor, Nurit; Weiss, Dror; Armoni, Roy | assign1 = | assign2 = | class = }}</ref> A first patent application was filed in 2008, followed by an extension in 2009,<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.freshpatents.com/-dt20090827ptan20090216712.php | title=Methods for calculating a combined impact analysis repository | publisher=Fresh Patents | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> and a continuation in 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.freshpatents.com/-dt20130214ptan20130041886.php | title=Methods for calculating a combined impact analysis repository | publisher=Fresh Patents | date=14 February 2013 | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2010, shares of [[Tamares Group]], a [[private equity]] investment firm based in [[Vaduz]], [[Liechtenstein]], were acquired by Panaya as part of fundraising round.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tamares.com/portfolio/selected-investments-private/panaya | title=Panaya Portfolio | publisher=Tamares | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2012, [[CGI Group]], a Canadian [[multinational corporation|multinational]] [[information technology]] (IT) consulting company, announced the launching of a new Panaya Practice.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cgi.com/en/cgi-sap-expertise-panaya-practice | title=CGI deepens its SAP expertise by launching its Panaya Practice | publisher=CGI | date=14 May 2012 | accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref>
In 2013 and 2014, Panaya laid off more than 25% of the company.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.themarker.com/technation/1.2033661|title=פיטורים בחברת התוכנה Panaya: קיצצה כ-15% מכוח האדם|last=הירשאוגה|first=אור|newspaper=TheMarker|access-date=2016-12-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.calcalist.co.il/internet/articles/0,7340,L-3638946,00.html|title=פאנאיה פיטרה יותר מ-23% מעובדיה - לאחר שהודיעה שתגייס עובדים|date=2014-08-21|newspaper=כלכליסט - www.calcalist.co.il|access-date=2016-12-18}}</ref> In 2016, Panaya shut down their Israeli-based sales development and moved them to Boston and the United Kingdom and replaced their CEO.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/company/panaya|title=Panaya: Overview|last=|first=|date=|website=LinkedIn|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
In June 2014, [[Deloitte]] and Panaya announced an agreement to provide [[Oracle Applications|Oracle E-business Suite]] customers the ability to reduce the cost and risk of application change projects.<ref>{{cite press release | url=http://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/about-deloitte/articles/press-releases/oracle-ebs-upgrades.html | title=Deloitte and Panaya enter Strategic Alliance to accelerate Oracle EBS upgrades and deployments | publisher=Deloitte | date=10 June 2014 | accessdate=5 December 2014}}</ref>
In February 2015, Infosys announced the acquisition of Panaya for a reported $200 million.<ref>https://techcrunch.com/2015/02/15/infosys-panaya/</ref> Prior to the sale, Panaya was in crisis and was on the verge of shut down, after many waves of layoffs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-infosys-buys-israels-panaya-for-230m-1001010261|title=Infosys buys Israel's Panaya for $230m - Globes English|website=Globes|access-date=2016-12-18}}</ref> In 2017, whistleblowers alleged that there were issues with the company’s acquisition by Infosys and that top executives of the company had personal interest in acquisition.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/another-whistleblower-mail-alleges-issues-with-infosys-panaya-deal/articleshow/57244175.cms |title= Another Whistleblower Mail Alleges Issues with Infosys’ Panaya Deal |last= Phadnisl |first= Shilpa |publisher= The Times of India}}</ref>
==Investors==
Gemini Partners and Benchmark Capital were the first investors to fund Panaya with $5 million in April 2006.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000097742 | title=ERP solutions co Panaya raises $5m | publisher=Globes | date=31 May 2006 | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
In August 2009, Panaya secured $5 million funding in a series B investment round led by Tamares Group with the participation of Benchmark Capital.<ref>{{cite press release | url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2009/08/04/idUS136999+04-Aug-2009+BW20090804 | title=Panaya Secures $5 Million in Series B Funding | publisher=Reuters | date=4 August 2009 | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref>
In June 2010, in a series C round, [[Battery Ventures]], [[Benchmark (venture capital firm)|Benchmark]] and [[Tamares Group]], invested a further $7 million.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000566121 | title=Software developer Panaya raises $7m | publisher=Globes | date=10 June 2010 | accessdate=22 December 2014 | author=Shelah, Shmulik}}</ref> In September 2010, HPV, the venture capital fund of [[Hasso Plattner]], co-founder of [[SAP AG]],<ref name="businessweek">{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=225290&ticker=SAP|title=Hasso Plattner: Executive Profile & Biography|work=investing.businessweek.com|accessdate=28 September 2012}}</ref> invested $6 million in exchange for company's stakes. Shares held by the Tamares Group, a private equity investment firm based in [[Vaduz]], Liechtenstein, were acquired by HPV together with existing investors Benchmark Capital and Battery ventures.
In 2013, the existing investors, in a series D funding round led by Battery Ventures and joined by Benchmark Capital and HPV, injected an additional $16 million into Panaya.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.globes.co.il/en/article-1000812822 | title=SaaS provider Panaya raises $16m | publisher=Globes | date=8 January 2013 | accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> The company has raised $39 million to date.
== In news == Infosys on 14 April, 2018 said it has started looking out for buyers of Skava and Panaya which were acquired during former CEO Vishal Sikka's tenure to build a so called software plus service model. The company has written off $90 Million in Panaya on a standalone basis, which is nearly half of the $200 million that it had paid to acquire the Israeli software firm in 2015.{{cn|date=June 2018}}
==Awards and recognition==

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Use Jamaican English|date=March 2012}} [[File:Peter Beckford jnr.jpg|thumb|right|Posthumous portrait of Peter Beckford by [[Benjamin West]]]] '''Peter Beckford (junior)''' (1672/3 – 1735) was a politician and businessman in early [[Colony of Jamaica|colonial Jamaica]].
He was the son of [[Peter Beckford]], founder of one of the most powerful families on the island, and briefly acting [[List_of_governors_of_Jamaica#Governors_of_Jamaica_(1690%E2%80%931962)|governor of the colony]]. Like his father, Beckford junior suffered a severe temper. As a young man, he was accused of killing the Deputy Judge Advocate of Jamaica in a fit of temper, but was acquitted after a lengthy court case.
Peter junior joined the [[House of Assembly of Jamaica]] and became the [[Speaker (politics)|Speaker]]. During a debate in 1710, things became extremely heated and some members drew their swords and threatened him. The Governor responded to shouts for assistance and the doors of the chamber were forced open. The Assembly was dissolved in the name of the Queen. The aged Peter Beckford senior was amongst those who had come to his rescue. In the general confusion, he slipped and fell down the long staircase. Suffering a mortal injury, he died soon after.
In 1720, Peter junior was one of the prominent people in Jamaica about whom the [[governors of Jamaica|governor]] Sir [[Nicholas Lawes]] complained had "anarchical principles". He went into business with [[Sir Alexander Grant, 5th Baronet|Alexander Grant]], leasing a storehouse from which the partners sold supplies to other plantation owners.<ref name="LBS">{{cite web|title=Sir Alexander Grant, 5th Bart.|url=https://www.ucl.ac.uk/lbs/person/view/2146632678|website=Legacies of British Slave-ownership|publisher=[[University College London]]|accessdate=6 April 2016}}</ref>
Peter married Bathshua Herring and they had thirteen children, including [[William Beckford (politician)|William]], who was twice Lord Mayor of London, and [[Elizabeth Howard, Countess of Effingham|Elizabeth]], who became Countess of Effingham. He died in 1735. His will included a legacy of £2,000 to found a school in [[Spanish Town]], which was started there in 1744. This school merged with another school started with £3,000 donated by Francis Smith forming the Beckford and Smith School in 1869.
His son [[William Beckford (politician)|William]] was born in 1709. William emigrated to England and had a prominent career in politics, defending the [[West India Interest]], i.e. lobbying against the [[abolitionism in the United Kingdom|abolition of slavery]], first as a [[Member of Parliament]] and then as [[Lord Mayor of London]].

[[File:Pierre Malotaux 1987.JPG|240px|thumb|Pierre Malotaux, Zeeland 1987-88.]] '''Pierre Charles-André Malotaux''' (28 April 1923 – 14 February 2016) was a Dutch organizational theorist, business consultant, and Professor of Business Administration at the [[Delft University of Technology]]. His is known with [[Jan in 't Veld]] for developing a specific [[systems approach]] to organizational problems, called the Delft Systems Approach.<ref>Rob Dekkers. ''(R)Evolution: Organizations and the Dynamics of the Environment.'' 2005. p. 429-434</ref><ref name="VOL 2008">Hans P. M. Veeke, [[Jaap A. Ottjes]] and [[Gabriël Lodewijks]] (2008). ''The Delft Systems Approach: Analysis and Design of Industrial Systems.'' Springer. p. viii</ref>
== Biography == === Youth, education and early career === Malotaux was born in [[Delft]] in 1923, the son of Robert Nicolas Marc August Malotaux (1898-1984) and Alice Cesarine Michiels (1897-1975). He was named after his grandfather, Pierre Malotaux, who came from [[Valenciennes]], France. He attended the [[Hogere Burgerschool]], where he graduated in 1940. In that year he started to study [[aerospace engineering]] at Delft University of Technology, where interrupted by the second World War he obtained his kandidaats exam in 1948 and his Engineering degree in 1951.
After graduating, he started his career at the [[Koninklijke Hoogovens]] in IJmuiden in 1951 at the psychotechnical department. From 1953 to 1959 he was consultant at a consultancy agency for business economics.<ref>Malotaux et al. (1998, p 147)</ref> In 1959 he settled as independent business consultant, and participated in the working group on business administration at the Koninklijk Instituut van Ingenieurs.
=== Further career === In 1968 at the Delft University of Technology he was appointed Professor of Business Administration at the Department of General Science. The first Professor of Business Administration in Delft had been appointed in 1909 and Malotaux was the six professor in a row. He predecessor Jacob Louis Mey had served from 1964 to 1965. However, instead of appointed one successor, in 1968 three professors were appointed: Malotaux, [[Jan in 't Veld]], and [[Henk Lombaers]]. Malotaux was to focus on general aspects of business theory, In 't Veld on industrial organization and Lombaerts on [[Operations research]].<ref>Malotaux et al. (1969)</ref>
In cooperation with [[Jan in 't Veld]] and several other engineers and social scientists, Malotaux developed a specific systems approach to organizational problems, which is called the Delft Systems Approach.<ref name="VOL 2008"/> In the 1980s Malotaux was initiator of the national network on Reliability, Maintenance management and Maintenance technology company. Their publications on this subject gave a start on [[life cycle thinking]] about technical systems in the Netherlands.<ref>D.C. Kooijman, H.L. Swets, & Hugo Priemus. ''Programmering onderzoek technisch beheer vastgoed,'' 1990. p. 34</ref> In 1994 he was succeeded by Jan Willem Koolhaas, who left in 1998.<ref>Christiaan Jongeneel (1998). "[https://www.delta.tudelft.nl/article/koolhaas-begint-een-hotel Koolhaas begint een hotel]". In ''Delta,'' 17-12-1998. Accessed 12 december 2017.</ref>
In 2004 Malotaux received a Royal decoration and was invested as a Knight of the [[Order of Orange-Nassau]].{{CN|date=July 2018}} In the same year with Jan in 't Veld he was appointed honorable member to the KIVI NIRIA Business Administration department.
The PhD students of Malotaux (and year of graduation) have been Jan Willem Koolhaas (1980), Eduard Rudolf Muhring (1987), Willem Gerrit Monhemius (1990) and Riek Boswijk (1992).
Malotaux died 14 February 2016 in [[Bilthoven]].
== Selected publications == * Pierre Malotaux and J.J.D. van der Gon, ''[http://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid%3A8d6d42e3-f117-4afa-832b-cb600f8ff18f?collection=research Methode voor kwalitatief grenslaagonderzoek met behulp van gloeidraden zonder beinvloeding der stroming].'' Technische Hogeschool Delft, Aircraft Engineering, Report VTH-45, 1951. * Pierre Malotaux. ''[http://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid%3A25d6f49d-c3c4-4740-bf1e-ef648f0a715c?collection=research Subjectiveren en objectiveren]''. TH Delft inaugural lecture on thinking as a process, 1968. * Pierre Malotaux, [[Henk Lombaers]] and [[Jan in 't Veld]]. ''Trio-logie: Variaties over een thema uit de bedrijfsleer'', 1969. * Pierre Malotaux, [[Pieter Verburg]], [[Klaas Halbertsma]], and J.L. Boers (ed.). ''Organisatiewetenschap en praktijk''. Leiden : Stenfert Kroese, 1976. * Pierre Malotaux, [[Joop Doorman]] and [[Jan in 't Veld]]. ''Inleiding Methodologie: cursus 1977/78''. TU Delft, 1977. * D. J. Adriaanse, P.J.M. Maas and Pierre Malotaux. Delft : Delftse Universitaire Pers, 1980. * Pierre Malotaux. ''[http://repository.tudelft.nl/islandora/object/uuid%3A9cc2764b-3b08-4501-9323-f01463969d7c?collection=research Een tussenbalans]''. Departure speech TU Delft, 1994. * Pierre Malotaux, H.K. Boswijk and H. van der Heide. ''Sturen of drijven?''. Alphen aan den Rijn : Samsom BedrijfsInformatie, 1995. * Pierre Malotaux, A.H. Schaafsma and A.F. van der Touw.. ''Besturend vermogen: organisatie in verval en herstel''. {{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=February 2011}} {{advert|date=February 2011}} }} {{italic title}} '''''PCN Europe''''' (Processing and Control News) is a [[magazine]] launched in 2004 for [[industry]] professionals. It is published by Thomas Industrial Media BVBA.
==Information== 6 times a year, ''PCN Europe'' provides a digest of the latest products news and technologies available on the European market. In 2009, nearly 40 000 subscribers received ''PCN Europe''', mostly engineers and purchasing managers. ''PCN Europe'' also publishes newsletters and updates its website with daily news about new products and services available to the European market.
''IEN Europe''' is published in Super A4 format since 2009, in a new style and with an enriched content. It covers articles on latest technologies, interviews and views from market leaders, application stories as well as industry news.
The headquarters of the publication is located in [[Mechelen]] [[Belgium]].
Thomas Industrial Media BVBA is also present in France, Italy, Germany and Turkey. The company publishes as well other industrial publications and websites across Europe.
In English and distributed all across Europe: *[[Industrial Engineering News Europe]] (''IEN'') *Power In Motion (''PIM'') In French and distributed in France: *[[Produits Equipements Industriels]] (''PEI'') In German and distributed in Germany: *[[Technische Revue]] (TR) In Italian and distributed in Italy: * [[Industrial Engineering News Italia]] (''IEN Italia'') *''Manutenzione Tecnica e Management'' *''Il Distributore Industriale'' In Turkish and distributed in Turkey: *''Endustri Dunyasi''
==Circulation== The magazine is free and available only on request for industry professionals. Over 40 000 copies are distributed six times a year.

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} '''Richard J. Brenneke''' (December 5 1941 - July 23 2015<ref name=NYT/><ref>{{Cite web|url = http://obits.oregonlive.com/obituaries/oregon/obituary.aspx?n=richard-j-brenneke-luck&pid=175389598|title = Richard J. "Luck" Brenneke's Obituary on The Oregonian|website = The Oregonian|access-date = 2016-03-12}}</ref>) is a US businessman who testified in 1988 that he had worked in Southeast Asia with the CIA's [[Air America (airline)|Air America]],<ref name=NYT/> among other roles.<ref>Doyle McManus, ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 25 October 1988, [http://articles.latimes.com/1988-10-25/news/mn-285_1_hostage-negotiations/4 1980 Deal Alleged : Leads, Leaps of Faith in Hostage Tale]</ref> Brenneke testified to the Senate's [[Kerry Committee report|Kerry Committee]] on [[allegations of CIA drug trafficking]], and his evidence was considered by the [[House October Surprise Task Force]] on the 1980 [[October Surprise conspiracy theory|October Surprise affair]].
==Career== [[William Northrop]], an Israeli intelligence agent indicted in the [[Brokers of Death arms case]], testified at Brenneke's perjury trial in [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Oregon]] in April 1990. Northrop had previously worked with Brenneke in the CIA’s effort to supply the Afghan Resistance fighting the [[Russian Armed Forces|Russian Army]].<ref>18 Crile, George, CHARLIE WILSON’S WAR, Grove Press, New York, 2003, p. 372; [http://www.idfiles.com/rbdepo.htm Deposition of Richard J. Brenneke], Joint Investigation by the Arkansas State Attorney General's Office and the U.S. Congress, Little Rock, Arkansas, June 21, 1991.</ref>
In December 1986 Brenneke was listed by the ''[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]'' as one of 16 of a "cast of characters" involved in the Iran-Contra affair, describing him as "An Oregon real estate developer with extensive contacts in Iran. Says he was involved, with the [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]] and [[National Security Agency|NSA]], in an attempt to sell 39 F-4E fighter planes to Iran in 1985. Says he met with several Iranian officials."<ref>''[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]'', 7 December 1986, [http://articles.philly.com/1986-12-07/news/26068279_1_max-gomez-iran-arms-sale-first-arms-shipment The Iran-contra Arms Deal: A Cast Of Characters]</ref>
"Called before a Senate subcommittee on narcotics and international relations in 1988, Brenneke claimed to have run drugs from Colombia to the U.S. as part of a Contra supply operation. He also testified to having purchased arms in Czechoslovakia for the Nicaraguan rebels. That testimony was called ''slanderous'' by then-[[George H. W. Bush|Vice President Bush,]] and a 1989 Senate committee report concluded that Brenneke never had the Central Intelligence Agency connections he claimed."<ref name=Verdict/><ref>David Johnston, ''[[New York Times]]'', 11 June 1988, [https://www.nytimes.com/1988/06/11/us/senate-panel-s-top-republican-says-chairman-politicized-drug-inquiry.html Senate Panel's Top Republican Says Chairman Politicized Drug Inquiry]</ref>
===Rupp trial (1988)=== On 23 September 1988, Brenneke voluntarily testified at the sentencing hearing of Heinrich Rupp, a "close friend" who had been convicted of bank fraud.<ref name=Verdict/> Brenneke testified that Rupp believed he was acting on behalf of the CIA in carrying out the fraud, which Brenneke said was part of a much wider CIA scheme to gain funding for covert operations by defrauding [[savings and loan association]]s. Brenneke cited [[Indian Springs State Bank]] as an example - the bank had loaned money to [[Global International Airways]], a company involved in the [[Iran-Contra affair]], and the Iranian [[Farhad Azima]] had been a major shareholder of the bank and also owner of the airline.<ref name=Verdict/> A 1975 ID card Brenneke supplied to a ''[[Houston Post]]'' reporter showed Rupp as a pilot for the airline.<ref name=Verdict/>
Brenneke said that he and Rupp had been involved in various covert operations for the agency in the past. He said he and Rupp and been involved in such matters since Brenneke's days at the CIA's [[Air America (airline)|Air America]], beginning in 1967.<ref name=NYT>''[[New York Times]]'', 6 June 1990, [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/06/us/man-cleared-of-lying-in-remarks-on-reagan-aides-and-52-hostages.html Man Cleared of Lying in Remarks On Reagan Aides and 52 Hostages]</ref><ref name=Verdict/> As an example of the kind of covert operations he and Rupp had been involved in, Brenneke said that he and Rupp had been involved in some of the meetings at which the 1980 [[October Surprise conspiracy theory|October Surprise affair]] was arranged.<ref name=Verdict/> Brenneke said that on the night of 18 October 1980, Rupp had flown [[William Casey]] from Washington's National Airport to Paris' [[Le Bourget Airfield]] for a series of secret meetings. These meetings (on 19 and 20 October) involved negotiations between Iranian representatives and members of the Reagan-Bush campaign. Brenneke testified he was present at the last of three meetings, on the details of the cash and weapons involved, at which Casey and [[Donald Gregg]] were also present. Brenneke also testified that [[George H.W. Bush]] was present in Paris for the meetings, but a month after his deposition he amended his statement by letter to the judge, clarifying that his knowledge of Bush's presence was not first-hand but came from Rupp.<ref name=Verdict/>
===Perjury trial (1989 - 1990)=== For his role in the Rupp trial, Brenneke was charged with five counts of making false declarations to a federal judge, a charge slightly stronger than [[perjury]].<ref name=Wheeler>Marilynn Wheeler, [[Associated Press]], 6 May 1990, [http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1990/Jury-Foreman-Says-He-Never-Doubted-Brenneke-s-Innocence/id-26207f1adffd774dbedd323aeeb79095 Jury Foreman Says He Never Doubted Brenneke's Innocence]</ref> He was indicted on 12 May 1989, accused of lying about his and Rupp's CIA connections and about the October Surprise meetings.<ref name=Verdict/> The timing caused some speculation that the charges were intended to avoid political embarrassment for [[Donald Gregg]], whose Senate confirmation hearings for his appointment as Ambassador to South Korea began the same day: the charges prevented senators from raising accusations Brenneke had made in 1988 that Gregg had directed the [[Iran-Contra affair]] out of the Vice-President's office.<ref name=Verdict/><ref>Lee May, ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', 13 May 1989, [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-05-13/news/mn-2673_1_contra-supply-scheme-el-salvador-and-resupply-donald-p-gregg Panel Probes Ex-Bush Aide on Contra Supply Scheme]</ref> The prosecution offered Brenneke a deal that would keep him out of prison if he pleaded guilty; he refused.<ref name=Verdict/>
The prosecution produced a CIA personnel specialist who testified that he could not find Brenneke or Rupp in the Agency's employment records, but under cross-examination admitted that Rupp had been trained by the CIA's [[Intermountain Aviation]], and that the Agency had "files" on both Rupp and Brenneke. [[Frank Snepp]] testified that CIA contract agents were often not listed in employment records where the agents were involved in sensitive operations.<ref name=Verdict/> Two intelligence operatives from Texas testified to collaborating with Brenneke.<ref>Sandro Mitromaco, [http://www.larouchepub.com/eiw/public/1990/eirv17n21-19900518/eirv17n21-19900518_066-jury_refuses_to_buy_bushs_iran_c.pdf Jury refuses to buy Bush's Iran-Contra story], ''[[Executive Intelligence Review]]'' 17(21), 18 May 1990</ref> Donald Gregg testified that on 18 October 1980 he was not in Paris but on holiday in Delaware, providing in evidence family photographs he said were taken that weekend. A meteorologist testified that the sunny weather conditions made it highly unlikely that they had been taken that weekend in that location.<ref name=Verdict/> The prosecution failed to prove that Casey and Bush could not have attended the Paris meetings.<ref name=Verdict/> Defense witnesses included [[William Northrop]], an Israeli intelligence agent indicted in the [[Brokers of Death arms case]], which had been dropped in January 1989 on the grounds that the prosecution could not disprove the defendants' claims that they believed the planned arms shipments to Iran were or could be government-sanctioned. Northrop testified that Israeli arms shipments to Iran began "within a fortnight" of the Paris meeting.<ref name=Verdict/>
On 4 May 1990, after only five hours of deliberation, the jury found Brenneke "not guilty" on all five counts. Following the trial, jury foreman Mark Kristoff stated, "We were convinced that, yes, there was a meeting, and he was there and the other people listed in the indictment were there.... There never was a guilty vote.... It was 100 percent."<ref name=Verdict>David Armstrong and Alex Constantine, "The Verdict is Treason", ''[[Z Magazine]]''; July/August 1990. Key excerpts [http://www.skepticfiles.org/socialis/spriseoc.htm here] and via [http://groups.google.com google groups] search [http://groups.google.com/groups/search?hl=en&lr=&ie=UTF-8&oe=UTF-8&q=%22the+verdict+is+treason%22++brenneke+Armstrong+&qt_s=Search here]</ref>
===Brenneke's records=== In 1991, [[Peggy Adler]] was retained by Brenneke to co-author his autobiography.<ref name="hartford courant">{{cite news|url=http://articles.courant.com/1992-04-14/news/0000203264_1_october-surprise-richard-brenneke-bulletproof-vest|title=Research Draws Illustrator Into 'October Surprise' Intrigue|date=14 April 1992|journal=[[Hartford Courant]]| last = Bixby | first = Lyn |accessdate=24 August 2011}}</ref> Discovering evidence in his files contradicting some of his claims regarding his presence at [[October Surprise conspiracy]] meetings, she contacted former [[CIA]] agent-turned-journalist, [[Frank Snepp]]. Snepp included this evidence (of credit card receipts showing a presence in Portland when Brenneke said he was in Paris) in a February 1992 article he wrote for the ''[[Village Voice]]''.<ref name=surprise>{{cite web|url=http://www.fas.org/irp/congress/1992_cr/h920224-october.htm |title= October Surmise |first= Frank| last= Snepp | publisher = Congressional Record (reprinted from ''[[Village Voice]]'', 25 February 1992)|date= |accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> Adler's work was the subject of a chapter in [[Robert Parry (journalist)|Robert Parry]]'s book, ''"Trick or Treason: The October Surprise Mystery"'' and she was interviewed by [[PBS]]' ''[[Frontline (U.S. TV series)|Frontline]]'' in this regard, aired in April 1992.<ref name=frontline>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/programs/info/1016.html |title=Investigating the October Surprise|publisher=Frontline (PBS) |date=7 April 1992 |accessdate=30 August 2011}}</ref> In mid-1992, learning that the [[House October Surprise Task Force]] was investigating whether or not there actually had been an October Surprise, she contacted investigative journalist and author [[Steven Emerson]],<ref>{{cite journal|journal = [[American Journalism Review]]|title=No October Surprise | first =Steven | last = Emerson |date=March 1993 |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3138/is_n2_v15/ai_n28622664/pg_2/ | accessdate=9 September 2011 }}</ref> who put her in touch with the Task Force so that she could turn over to them the seventy cartons of documents she'd hauled east from Brenneke's home in Portland, Oregon, in order to write his memoirs. In the month of June Adler worked as a consultant to the Task Force.<ref name=TF1>[[Media:Charlie Rose TF Letter.pdf|Peggy Adler employed as an Assistant Investigator by the U.S. House of Representatives' October Surprise Task Force (pdf)]]</ref>
In a 17 December 1992 press conference at the [[National Press Club (United States)|National Press Club]], responding to the Senate report, Barbara Honegger (who published a book on October Surprise in 1989 on the day Brenneke was indicted for false declarations) introduced new evidence, saying that an expert [[graphology|graphologist]]'s examination of the critical credit card receipts for a motel and a restaurant in October 1980 indicated the handwriting was not Brenneke's. Honegger also said that a manager of the relevant restaurant who had been there since 1979 told her that no waitress by the name on the receipt had worked there. Honegger also spoke to the organisers of a Kendo tournament Brenneke was said to have attended, who told her that there was no record of Brenneke attending the event, while five eyewitnesses agreed that Brenneke had not been present on 19–20 October (one said he had been there on 18 October).<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rJl6FzmLBAY&feature=youtu.be October Surprise Press Conference - Barbara Honegger - 1992], c 8-20 mins into recording.</ref>
===Other matters=== In mid-1990 Brenneke provided documents to Italian journalists regarding [[Licio Gelli]] and [[Propaganda Due]] (P2), asserting CIA support for their activities.<ref>''[[La Repubblica]]'', 4 July 1990, [http://ricerca.repubblica.it/repubblica/archivio/repubblica/1990/07/04/gelli-agente-della-cia-la-parola.html GELLI E L' AGENTE DELLA CIA LA PAROLA E' AI MAGISTRATI ]</ref> Brenneke told [[Rai 1]] that he had been involved in CIA payments to P2 of $1–$10m per month or more, with the money used to finance terrorism and drug trafficking. The CIA rejected a FOIA request regarding Gelli on grounds of national security.<ref>Philip Willan (2002), ''Puppetmasters: The Political Use of Terrorism in Italy'', [[iUniverse]], pp77-82</ref><ref>Philip Willan (2013), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=AeufAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA94 The Vatican at War: From Blackfriars Bridge to Buenos Aires]'', [[iUniverse]], pp90-97</ref> Gelli and others were later convicted of subverting investigation into the 1980 [[Bologna Massacre]].
==References== <references/>

The term '''Safe Work Procedure''' (SWP) originated in [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria, Australia]], and is predominantly used as a [[risk management]] tool by industries throughout Australia, particularly in the [[mining]] sector. SWPs are also referred to using other terms, such as [[Standard Operating Procedure]] (SOPre) (SOP). A Safe Work Procedure is a step by step description of a process when deviation may cause a loss. This risk control document created by teams within the company describes the safest and most efficient way to perform a task. This document stays in the Health & Safety system for regular use as a template or guide when completing that particular task on site.
==Requirements of Safe Work ==
The document generally lists the associated hazards involved in performing a task, what risk score is associated with the hazards (using a [[risk matrix]]), what personal protective equipment is required, and the steps involved to complete the activity without incident.
The document is split up to meet the above requirements as follows; *[[Procedure (term)|Step]] *[[Hazard]]s *[[Inherent risk]] *[[Control measure]]s *[[Residual risk]]
Each person involved in that task on site must ensure all sections of the SWP are followed.
Safe Work Procedures are also required for machinery and equipment that is used to perform commercial activities. The procedures are required to be enforced within the workplace and improved as conditions or equipment changes.

|website=http://www.svetogorsk-city.ru/ |website_ref= |date=March 2014 }} '''Svetogorsk''' ({{lang-ru|Светого́рск}}; {{lang-fi|Enso}}) is an industrial [[types of inhabited localities in Russia|town]] It is located {{convert|1|km|sp=us}} from the [[Finnish–Russian border]], {{convert|5|km|sp=us}} from the Finnish town of [[Imatra]], and {{convert|207|km|sp=us}} from [[Saint Petersburg|St. Petersburg]]. Population: {{ru-census|p2010=15,981|p2002=15,698|p1989=15,594}}
==History== {{Quote box |width=27em |align=left |bgcolor=#B0D4DE |title=Historical affiliations |fontsize=85% |quote=<poem>{{flagicon image|Coat of Arms of Grand Duchy of Finland-holding sabre.svg}} [[Grand Duchy of Finland]] ([[Russian Empire]]) 1887-1917 {{flag|Republic of Finland}} 1917–1940 {{flag|Soviet Union|1936}} 1940–1941 {{flag|Republic of Finland}} 1941–1944 {{flag|Soviet Union}} 1944–1991 {{flag|Russian Federation}} 1991–present</poem> }} Originally called '''Enso''',<ref name="LesogorskyDHist">{{cite web|url=http://classif.spb.ru/sprav/np_lo/74_Jaskinsky_Lesogorsky_rayon.htm|script-title=ru:Яскинский район (ноябрь 1944 г. - октябрь 1948 г.), Лесогорский район (октябрь 1948 г. - декабрь 1960 г.)|publisher=Система классификаторов исполнительных органов государственной власти Санкт-Петербурга|language=Russian|accessdate=March 21, 2014}}</ref> it was founded in 1887<ref name="Est">Official website of Leningrad Oblast. {{cite web|title=Town of Svetogorsk|url=http://eng.lenobl.ru/gov/municipal/svetogorsk?result=1|work=lenobl.ru|accessdate=April 28, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140429045413/http://eng.lenobl.ru/gov/municipal/svetogorsk?result=1|archivedate=April 29, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref> to serve a paper mill. At the time, it was a part of [[Vyborg Governorate]] in the [[Grand Duchy of Finland]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} In 1919, Finland became independent and the governorate was transformed into [[Viipuri Province]]. Enso became a part of the Jääski Municipality, with the seat in [[Lesogorsky|Jääski]]. [[File:Финская вилла.jpg|thumb|left|The Finnish villa (1930) at Kantorovicha Street]]
The territory was ceded by [[Finland]] to the [[Soviet Union]] by the [[Moscow Peace Treaty]] as a result of the [[Winter War]]. After the Winter War, the Finns and the Soviets disagreed on the interpretation of the peace treaty regarding Enso. The former Minister for Foreign Affairs of Finland [[Väinö Tanner]] wrote in his memoirs: "Already now a dispute about the district of Enso developed. According to the map attached to the peace treaty Enso was clearly intended to belong to Finland but the Russians claimed that it should belong to them. Later the map was redrawn according to the interests of the Russians so that the border bends at Enso." <ref>{{cite book|last=Tanner|first=Väinö|title=Olin ulkoministerinä talvisodan aikana|trans-title=I Was Foreign Minister During Winter War|page=415|language=Finnish|publisher=Tammi|year=1950}}</ref>
In March 1940, Enso became a part of [[Lesogorsky District|Yaskinsky District]] with the [[administrative center]] in the [[urban-type settlement|work settlement]] of [[Lesogorsky|Yaski]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} It was a part of the [[Karelian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic]], after March 31, 1940 of the [[Karelo-Finnish Soviet Socialist Republic]].<ref name="KASSR">{{cite web|url=http://istmat.info/files/uploads/17632/sssr_ad-ter_delenie_1941_karelo-finskaya_ssr.pdf|script-title=ru:Карело-Финская ССР|publisher=Handbook of administrative divisions of Soviet Union|language=Russian|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref> [[File:Ryti Mannerheim.JPG|thumb|left|[[Carl Gustaf Emil Mannerheim]], Marshal of Finland, and [[Risto Ryti]], President of Finland in Enso on June 4, 1944]] Enso was recaptured by Finns between 1941 and 1944 during the [[Continuation War]] but was again ceded to Soviets by the [[Moscow Armistice]]. This secession was formalized after signing the [[Paris Peace Treaties, 1947|Paris Peace Treaty]] in 1947. The Finnish population was resettled to Finland,<ref name="hist1">{{cite web|url=http://vbglenobl.ru/raion/istoriya-raiona|script-title=ru:История Выборгского района, история Выборгской земли|trans-title=The history of the Vyborgsky District, the history of the Vyborg land |publisher=Муниципальное образование Выборгский район Ленинградской Области|language=Russian|accessdate=March 21, 2014}}</ref> while migrants from Central Russia resettled the Karelian Isthmus.
On November 24, 1944, Yaskinsky District was transferred from Karelo-Finnish SSR to Leningrad Oblast.<ref name="LesogorskyDHist" /> On October 1, 1948, the district was renamed Lesogorsky and on January 13, 1949, all Finnish names of the localities were replaced with Russian names.<ref name="LesogorskyDHist" /> In particular, Enso was renamed Svetogorsk.<ref name="LesogorskyDHist" /> On December 9, 1960, Lesogorsky District was abolished and merged into Vyborgsky District.<ref name="LesogorskyDHist" />
In 1972, the Soviet Union awarded Finland a construction project for a large new cellulose and paper mill in Svetogorsk. The project was paid with Soviet crude oil. The project also gave a start to cross-border relations. Notably, the construction workers in Svetogorsk were called "builders", and the project also had intent to "build friendship between peoples".
On April 18, 2008, about five hundred inhabitants of Svetogorsk participated in a protest which included a road barricade on the [[Finnish–Russian border]] as a protest against poor road conditions and lack of investment in road improvement at both federal and municipal level. According to the Finnish public service broadcaster [[Yle]], the militia{{clarification needed|date=March 2014}}<!--the [[militsiya|police]] or the protesters' militia?--> participated in effectively cutting off through traffic. The main issue of discontent was the lack of a bypass, which, according to reports, should have already been built.<ref>{{cite news|title=Mielenosoittajat sulkivat rajaliikenteen Svetogorskissa|agency=YLE Uutiset|publisher=YLE|date=May 24, 2012|url=http://www.yle.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/oikea/id88309.html|accessdate=June 20, 2013}}<!--If this URL dies, try this one: http://yle.fi/uutiset/mielenosoittajat_sulkivat_rajaliikenteen_svetogorskissa/5832264--></ref>
==Administrative and municipal status== [[File:Svetogorsk.jpg|thumb|Apartment buildings in Svetogorsk]] Within the [[subdivisions of Russia#Administrative divisions|framework of administrative divisions]], it is, together with the [[urban-type settlement]] of [[Lesogorsky]] and two [[types of inhabited localities in Russia|rural localities]], incorporated within [[Vyborgsky District, Leningrad Oblast|Vyborgsky District]] as '''Svetogorskoye [[Town of district significance|Settlement Municipal Formation]]'''.<ref name="LeningradO_adm">Oblast Law #32-oz</ref> As a [[subdivisions of Russia#Municipal divisions|municipal division]], Svetogorskoye Settlement Municipal Formation is incorporated within Vyborgsky Municipal District as '''Svetogorskoye Urban Settlement'''.<ref name="LeningradOVyborgskyD_mun">Law #17-oz</ref>
==Economy== ===Industry=== Before the [[Winter War]], the town was a major factory site for [[Stora Enso|Enso-Gutzeit Oy]], the Finnish pulp and paper company (now [[Stora Enso]]). In the 1940 [[Moscow Peace Treaty]], the new Finnish-Soviet border was deliberately drawn to leave the factory complex on the Soviet side. The town's major industry is still [[pulp and paper industry|pulp and paper]].
OAO ''Svetogorsk'', one of the biggest [[paper mill]]s in Russia, is the major employer. Covering {{convert|2|km2|sp=us}}, OAO ''Svetogorsk'' produces [[pulp (paper)|pulp]], printing [[paper]], and packaging board. Its brands include ''[[Svetocopy]]'' and ''Ballet'' office paper. Since December 1998, OAO ''Svetogorsk'' has been majority owned by [[International Paper]]. At end of 2001, the plant employed 3,000 people; by 2008 this had fallen to 2,200.{{fact|date=September 2016}}
Immediately adjacent to OAO ''Svetogorsk'' is a tissue mill. This formed part of the original mill complex but was split-away and resold by International Paper to [[Svenska Cellulosa Aktiebolaget|SCA]] during the acquisition of OAO ''Svetogorsk'' from [[Tetra Pak|Tetra Laval]], which controlled the plant since 1995. ''Svetogorsk Tissue'', as the separate entity was to be called, became fully integrated into SCA Hygiene Products Division in 2003 (called [[Essity]] since 2017). It employs around four hundred people. Its products include ''[[Zewa]]'' and ''[[SCA Tissue Europe|Tork]]'' brands of paper towels and [[toilet paper]].
===Border crossing=== The [[Imatra]]–Svetogorsk [[Finnish–Russian border|border]] crossing plays a key role in the transportation of timber between Russia and Finland. Also, around 150 employees commute daily from Imatra to the paper mills. The border crossing, which had temporary status, was a frequent cause of bottlenecks due to lengthy customs checks and inadequate facilities. A Russia-Finland agreement in 1997 allowed the development and eventual permanence of the border crossing. This €7 million [[European Union]] [[Technical Aid to the Commonwealth of Independent States|TACIS]]-funded project ran from 1999 and the new international frontier, capable of handling 1,300 cars per day, opened on July 3, 2002.
===Transportation=== Svetogorsk is connected by railway with [[Kamennogorsk]], where it has connection to the old [[Vyborg–Joensuu railroad]]. There is suburban traffic to [[Vyborg]]. The continuation of the railroad beyond Svetogorsk to the [[Finnish–Russian border]] is disused.
Svetogorsk is connected by roads with Kamennogorsk and Vyborg, as well as with [[Imatra]] across the border.
==Sister city== Svetogorsk has one [[twin towns and sister cities|sister city]]:<ref>[http://www.47news.ru/2009/02/03/015/ Svetogorsk is getting a sister city]</ref> *{{Flagicon|Finland}} [[Imatra]], [[Finland]]

(corporation)|Société Anonyme Égyptienne]] | traded_as = {{Unbulleted list|{{EGX|ETEL}}|{{LSE|TEEG}}|[[EGX 30]] component}} | industry = [[Telecommunication]]s | founded = {{Start date and age|1881}} | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | hq_location_city = [[Cairo]] | hq_location_country = [[Egypt]] | area_served = Egypt | key_people = [[Magued Osman]] {{small|([[Chairman]])}} | brands = WE | operating_income = [[E£]] 1.4 billion | income_year = Q1 2018 | assets = [[E£]]32 billion | assets_year = Q1 2018 | equity = [[E£]]26 billion | equity_year = Q1 2018 | owner = [[Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (Egypt)|Ministry of Communications and Information Technology]] {{small|(80%)}} | num_employees = 53,332 | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | subsid = {{Unbulleted list|[[TE Data]]|WE}} | website = {{URL|te.eg}} }}
'''Telecom Egypt''' ({{lang-arz|المصرية للاتصالات}}), is [[Egypt]]'s primary [[telephone company]]. It started in 1854 with the first telegraph line in [[Egypt]]. In 1998, it replaced the former Arab Republic of Egypt National Telecommunication Organization (ARENTO).
The company has a fixed-line subscriber base in excess of 6 million subscribers.
Telecom Egypt acquired [[TEData]] (formerly GegaNet) in late 2001 to act as its [[data communications]] and [[ISP]] arm. The company has another [[Information technology|IT]] arm, Xceedcc - Xceed contact center - located in Egypt's Smart Village. <!-- Unsourced image removed: [[Image:Xceed_Contact_Center.jpg|thumb|right|Xceedcc Building in Smart Village]] -->Telecom Egypt also owns 44.95% of [[Vodafone Egypt]]. Telecom Egypt has adopted the contemporary quality integration trends and established the quality sector in 2001, which is now preparing the whole company to take the [[International Organization for Standardization|ISO]] [[ISO 9000|9001-2000]] certificate.
Its main operational offices are in [[Cairo]], [[Al Mansurah]], [[Ismailia]], [[Alexandria]], [[Suez]] and [[Tanta]].<ref name="TelecomEgypt">{{cite book|last1=CIA|first1=United States|title=The CIA World Factbook 2010, Book 2010|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing Inc.|isbn=9781602397279|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pqanFyF6nI0C&pg=PA209&dq=Egyptian+telephone+system,+Tanta&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjP2pT1-q3QAhXKrlQKHbrPC4kQ6AEIXTAH#v=onepage&q=Egyptian%20telephone%20system%2C%20Tanta&f=false|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
On August 31, 2016, Telecom Egypt (TE) became a fully-fledged mobile operator after agreeing to pay E£7.08 billion (€713.14 million) for a 4G licence.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/3/12/242070/Business/Economy/Telecom-Egypt-becomes-the-countrys-first-operator-.aspx|title=Telecom Egypt becomes the country's first operator to secure 4G licence - Economy - Business - Ahram Online|website=english.ahram.org.eg|language=en|access-date=2018-07-18}}</ref>
On September 18, 2017, Telecom Egypt launched its mobile service, branded as '''WE'''.
==History==
===Origins=== The government initiative that later became Telecom Egypt started as a telegraph line between the [[Cairo Governorate|Governorate of Cairo]] and the [[Alexandria Governorate|Governorate of Alexandria]] in 1854 <ref>{{cite web|title=Telecom Egypt goes live with Ascade's Routing Solution|url=http://www.ascade.com/about-us/news/telecom-egypt-press-release/|accessdate=3 April 2012}}</ref> built by the British Eastern Telegraph Company.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Period of Muhammad Ali|url=http://www.egyptianagriculture.com/muhammad_ali.html|accessdate=3 April 2012}}</ref> Egypt's first telephone line was installed between Cairo and Alexandria in 1881. In 1881, the Egyptian government purchased the Eastern Telephone Company and created the Telephone and Telegraph Authority.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Information Society Watch - Egypt|url=http://www.giswatch.org/en/country-report/civil-society-participation/egypt}}</ref> Under Law No. 107 of 1957, all assets of the Eastern Company and other telecommunications providers were transferred to the Ministry of Telecommunications. In the same year, Presidential Decree No. 709 placed all wire and wireless communications under the jurisdiction of the Wire and Wireless Communications Authority which reported to the Ministry of Transport.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hashish|first=Mohamed|title=The Egyptian Legislation Governing the Information and Communication Technology Sector|url=http://www.arablegalportal.org/financial/legaldocs/ICT/egypt/Egypt-ICT-legislation.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303215505/http://www.arablegalportal.org/financial/legaldocs/ICT/egypt/Egypt-ICT-legislation.pdf|archivedate=2016-03-03|df=}}</ref> The Arab Republic of Egypt National Telecommunications Organization (ARENTO) was established in 1980 as an autonomous public utility reporting to the Ministry of Transport.<ref>{{cite book|last=Gala|first=Ahmed|title=Welfare Impact of Telecom Reform in Egypt: An Ex Ante Analysis|year=1999|publisher=World Bank|editor=Samiha Fawzy and Ahmed Gala|accessdate=3 April 2012}}</ref> Via Law No. 19 of 1998, ARENTO was renamed Telecom Egypt and turned into a joint stock company over which the government maintained full ownership.<ref name="merisratings1">{{cite web|title=Middle East Rating & Investor Service: Telecom Egypt S.A.E.|url=http://www.merisratings.com/UserFiles/File/Telecom%20Egypt%20Report.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225211441/http://www.merisratings.com/UserFiles/File/Telecom%20Egypt%20Report.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2010-12-25}}</ref>
===Telecom liberalization and Telecom Egypt=== Telecom Egypt replaced ARENTO in 1998 and the [[Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (Egypt)|Ministry of Communications and Information Technology]] was founded in order to develop Egypt's information and communications technology infrastructure.<ref name="merisratings1"/> In 2001, Telecom Egypt established TE Data, a data and communications subsidiary. In the same year, Telecom Egypt was awarded a license to begin mobile operations in Egypt but declined. Instead, TE purchased an 8.6% share in Vodafone Egypt in 2003. Telecom Egypt gradually increased their holdings in Vodafone Egypt until the end of 2008, when their share was 44.95%. Today, Vodafone Egypt represents a significant source of revenue for Telecom Egypt.<ref name="nbkcapital1">{{cite web|title=Telecom Egypt: Day by Day Tactics|url=http://www.nbkcapital.com/BR/Research/MER/Telecom%20Sector/Egypt/Telecom%20Egypt/NBK%20Capital-Telecom%20Egypt%20Initiation%20of%20Coverage-22Dec.2009.pdf|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101220155644/http://nbkcapital.com/BR/Research/MER/Telecom%20Sector/Egypt/Telecom%20Egypt/NBK%20Capital-Telecom%20Egypt%20Initiation%20of%20Coverage-22Dec.2009.pdf|archivedate=2010-12-20|df=}}</ref>
In November 2005, the Egyptian government launched an [[Initial Public Offering|IPO]] of 20% of Telecom Egypt's existing share capital. In 2006, the National Telecom Regulatory Authority (NTRA) deregulated Telecom Egypt's monopoly over domestic and international telephone service, and announced the potential for another fixed-line operator. This initiative was put on hold due to economic pressure, and Telecom Egypt is still Egypt's only fixed line operator.<ref name="nbkcapital1"/>
Due to the government's 80% share in the company, Telecom Egypt is beholden to the Ministry of Communications and Information Technology (MCIT) for all major decisions concerning finances, tariffs and employment. The MCIT is seen by some to exert control over the National Telecom Regulatory Authority, leading to potential conflicts of interest.<ref>{{cite book|title=Competitiveness and Private Sector Development: Egypt|year=2010|publisher=OECD|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QMFXAhLlaMYC&pg=PA104 }}</ref>
In an interview <ref>{{cite web|title=New unified licence means Telecom Egypt likely to break relationship with Vodafone, says CEO|year=2014|publisher=Global Telecoms Business |url=http://www.globaltelecomsbusiness.com/Article/3351421/Interviews/25239/New-unified-licence-means-Telecom-Egypt-likely-to-break-relationship-with-Vodafone-says-CEO.html}}</ref> published in May–June 2014, Telecom Egypt's CEO said that the company was awarded a unified telecoms licence in April 2014, but he said that this would lead to a change in the relationship with Vodafone Egypt, in which Telecom Egypt has a stake of just under 45%. Telecom Egypt will be able to offer mobile services under the terms of the new licence, he said, and will be using new 4G spectrum from 2015, and that would lead to a break-up of the relationship with [[Vodafone]], by Telecom Egypt either buying the rest of the Vodafone Egypt stake or selling its stake to the Vodafone group.
==Products and services== Telecom Egypt is Egypt's only fixed-line operator, and one of the largest in the [[MENA]] region with over 9 million subscribers as of 2009. The company offers services in two categories, retail and wholesale. On the retail side, Telecom Egypt offers access and voice services for home and enterprises and data services through TE Data. TE Data had a 61% market share in Egypt in 2009 and also operates in [[Jordan]]. TE Data offers additional services through a collaboration with the [[Microsoft Live]] platform. Telecom Egypt is Egypt's only supplier of wholesale services. The company leases broadband capacity as well as national and international interconnection services in both data and voice. Telecom Egypt also provides infrastructure and transport services, voice and data services, and hosting. Whole services accounted for 42% of revenues in 2009. Telecom Egypt also offers mobile services through its stake in Vodafone Egypt.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Report: Egypt 2010|year=2010|publisher=Oxford Business Group|pages=91–92|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fyTZkEUNIHoC&pg=PA91&dq=telecom+egypt&hl=en&sa=X&ei=koR6T-mcFqLy0gHLtayfBg&ved=0CEwQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=telecom%20egypt&f=false}}</ref> Overall, Telecom Egypt has a public monopoly over fixed landlines, provides 70% of internet service in Egypt, is the only provider of international phone service,<ref>{{cite news|last=Hussein|first=Marwa|title=Telecom Egypt employees escalate their protest, demanding release of 5 colleagues|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/24500.aspx|accessdate=3 April 2012|newspaper=Al Ahram Online}}</ref> and provides connectivity to all mobile operators.<ref name="nbkcapital1"/> Though Telecom Egypt has recently applied to be a virtual network operator of mobile services in Egypt, perceived market domination might prevent a direct entry into the mobile phone market.
===Retail services=== Telecom Egypt offers fixed-line voice services and mobile through their partnership with Vodafone Egypt. They offer broadband internet and [[IPTV]] services as well as "enterprise-managed internet access, managed network services, and outsourcing of information and communication technologies services".<ref name="nbkcapital1"/>
===Wholesale=== Telecom Egypt offers wholesale services to domestic and international customers. <ref name="nbkcapital1"/> Internationally, Telecom Egypt is becoming a telecommunications and data hub between Asia, Africa, and Western Europe. The TE North cable, built in collaboration with [[Alcatel-Lucent]], is a 40G undersea cable that connects [[Abu Talat, Egypt]], to [[Marseille]], [[France]], with branches to Jordan, Cyprus and branching units to be used for further expansion. It began operation in mid-2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=Alcatel-Lucent helps Telecom Egypt to put first 40G Mediterranean system in service|url=http://www.telecomindiaonline.com/alcatel-lucent-helps-telecom-egypt-to-put-first-40g-mediterranean-system-in-service.html|accessdate=3 April 2012}}</ref>

==Controversies==
===2011 shutdown=== Just after midnight on January 28, Egypt's international data connections were shut down in 25 minutes. Telecom Egypt, as one of the five major network providers in Egypt, and the owner of "virtually all the country's fiber-optic cables" was instrumental in the government's shutdown. The government also used its hold over Telecom Egypt's infrastructure to leverage providers like Vodafone Egypt into shutting down their services. If these companies did not shut down independently, the reversal of the government's method of blocking their services would've taken more time to reverse.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt Leaders Found ‘Off’ Switch for Internet|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/16/technology/16internet.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|accessdate=3 April 2012|newspaper=New York Times|date=February 15, 2011|author=James Glanz|author2=John Markoff}}</ref>
In April 2011, a lawsuit was brought to the High Administrative Court seeking damages from three telecommunications companies (including Telecom Egypt) as well as current and former officials. The verdict eventually reached, which held accountable officials but not companies, stated that the internet shutdown had been practiced as early as April 2008, during the [[2008 Egyptian general strike|Mahalla Al Kobra protests]] in conjunction with telecom companies and ISPs in Egypt, and again in October 2010.<ref>{{cite news|last=El-Wardani|first=Salma|title=Outrage over exoneration of Egypt telecom giants in communications shutdowns|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/13296.aspx|accessdate=3 April 2012|newspaper=[[Al-Ahram]] Online|date=June 1, 2011}}</ref>
In addition to the shutdown, mobile operators' networks, including Vodafone Egypt's, were hijacked by the Egyptian government in order to send text messages directly to customers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt Intrudes On Mobile Operators|url=http://www.tectrends.com/tectrends/article/00178752.html|accessdate=3 April 2012|date=February 4, 2011|author=Paul Sonne|author2=Max Colchester}}</ref>
===2011 sit In=== On October 12, 2011, five Telecom Egypt employees were detained by police and charged with attempted murder of the company's CEO Mohamed Abdel Rahim. According to protestors, the CEO visited the offices and employees gathered at his office to present demands associated with working conditions at Telecom Egypt. After he refused to hear their demands, they staged a sit-in in front of his office, which eventually ended when military police cut into his office from an adjacent room.
Protestors organized a protest and strike calling for the release of their co-workers. Telephone directory services and the Telecom Egypt service hotline were shut down in protest as well. The protestors claimed that Abdel Rahim and the board of directors were responsible for corruption and called for their resignation as well as the revision of high officials' salaries.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hussein|first=Marwa|title=Telecom Egypt employees escalate their protest, demanding release of 5 colleagues|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/24500.aspx|accessdate=3 April 2012|newspaper=Al Ahram Online|date=October 18, 2011}}</ref>
On October 23, 2011, the head of the independent workers union of Telecom Egypt, Mohamed Abu Karish, said that the prisoners would be released and disputed claims that workers threatened to shut down internet and communication services as an attempt to undermine the protest.<ref>{{cite news|last=Al-Lakani|first=Adel|title=Telecom Egypt workers should see colleagues released soon|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/24836.aspx|accessdate=3 April 2012|newspaper=Al Ahram Online|date=October 23, 2011}}</ref> Abdel Rahim withdrew his murder accusation and the detainees were set free on October 25.<ref>{{cite news|last=Megahed|first=Mohamed|title=Telecom Egypt CEO withdraws attempted murder accusation|url=http://www.egyptindependent.com/node/508513|accessdate=3 April 2012|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm English Online|date=October 25, 2012}}</ref>

{{orphan|date=February 2018}} '''William Hamilton Biney''' was a Ghanaian businessman who built a large [[stevedore]] company in [[Lagos]].
Biney was a philanthropist and a generous businessmen who had friends all over the country. His house in Lagos served as residence to many traditional rulers vising the former capital.
==Life== Biney was born in the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]], now [[Ghana]] in 1896. After his elementary education in the Gold Coast, he went to Sierra Leone and attended the Wesleyan Boys High School, Freetown, completing studies in 1904. Biney immigrated to Nigeria in 1911 and settled in Lagos. He initially worked as a bookeeper for [[Alexander Miller (merchant)|Miller Bros]] but in 1918, he left the firm and began working as a sub-contractor to [[Elder Dempster]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Forrest|first1=Tom|title=The advance of African capital : the growth of Nigerian private enterprise|date=1994|publisher=Univ. Press of Virginia|location=Charlottesville|isbn=9780813915623|page=23|edition=1. publ. in the United States of America.}}</ref>
A pioneer in stevedoring, he founded W. Biney & co in 1918 as a labor contracting firm providing loading and offloading services at the quay to firms such as [[United Africa Company|UAC]]. The company started with two sheds and expanded as port activities grew. The company was also involved in the offloading of kerosene and petrol at the [[Ijora]] Wharf from firms such as [[Vacuum Oil Company]], and it later added railway contracting services. In 1959, the firm was involved the establishment of stevedoring business in Tema, Ghana. The firm was highly respected and up till 1964 was the sole contractor handling loading and offloading of cargoes in [[Apapa]].
Biney was also involved in labour related activities, in 1941, he established a privately funded labour registration bureau<ref>{{cite journal|title=Business Directory of West Africa (International).|date=1872|volume=13|page=74|language=en}}</ref> and a bulletin on labour issues.
Biney established a zoo, the first privately own zoo in Nigeria, he was a boxing patron and horticulturist. He was a foundation member of the Island Club.

[[File:DNA Digest editathon at Wayra 2014-05-29.jpg|thumb|upright|Group activity in shared meeting space at the Wayra Academy in London.]] '''Wayra''' is a [[seed accelerator|start-up accelerator]] which was started in Latin America and Spain in 2011 as an initiative of [[Telefónica]]'s chief executive in Europe, [[José María Álvarez-Pallete]].<ref>{{citation|last=Solon |first=Olivia |url=https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2012-03/07/wayra |title=Telefónica invites UK startups to join accelerator programme Wayra |journal=Wired |date=7 March 2012 }}</ref><ref name=talent>{{citation |chapter=6. Creating a talent eco-system |title=Managing Talent: Recruiting, Retaining and Getting the Most from Talented People |author=Michel Syrett, Marion Devine |publisher=Profile Books |year=2014 |isbn=9781847658104}}</ref>
The [[startup company|start-up companies]] receive funding, office space and [[mentoring]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.o2.co.uk/?press-release=wayra-uk-selects-new-start-ups |title=Wayra UK selects new start-ups |publisher=O2 |date=28 March 2013 |work=The Blue}}</ref> The manager of the Wayra Academy in London explained their business strategy, "It's not just about the ideas. We are using Wayra as a way of acquiring great talent for Telefónica."<ref name=talent/>
The first Wayra started in Colombia in mid 2011 and expanded to ten more countries that year.<ref>{{citation |page=49 |title=50 Ways to Find Funding for Your Business |author=Emma Jones |publisher=Harriman House |year=2013 |isbn=9780857192905}}</ref> In 2013, there were 14 Wayra academies in 12 countries in Europe and Latin America and Telefónica planned to support about 350 startups altogether.<ref>{{cite web|author=John Kennedy |url=http://www.siliconrepublic.com/start-ups/item/33605-telefonicas-wayra-accelera |title=Telefónica’s Wayra accelerator in Dublin reveals shortlist of start-ups for second intake |publisher=Silicon Republic |date=25 July 2013}}</ref><ref name=talent/> In March 2015, Telefónica closed down the Wayra in Prague, as part of Telefónica's general exit from that market.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wayracee.com/wayra-cee-to-end-operations-in-march/ |title=Wayra CEE to end operations in March |publisher=Wayra CEE}}</ref> In 2015, Volo, which had been started at the Munich Wayra, was sold to [[Rocket Internet]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2015/04/16/volo/ |title=Rocket Internet Acquires Restaurant Delivery Service Volo |publisher=Techcrunch}}</ref>
